list_page_teaser: Luke Skywalker, Leia Organa, and Han Solo have different personalities, but get along very well.  Click to learn more!
description_html:
This gallery contains spiritual portraits of the main characters in the Star Wars Original Trilogy.

To see the personalities of some Jedi Masters and droids, see the Jedi Masters and droids gallery. To see the personalities of main characters in the prequel trilogy — including Darth Vader and Emporer Palpatine — see the prequel trilogy gallery on this site.
story_html:
These three people make a good team.

The Blue in Luke's spiritual portrait shows that he, with his Jedi training, is the deep, idealistic one. His image looks very similar to Yoda's and Obi-Wan Kenobi's.

The Green in Leia's spiritual portrait shows she is, by a small margin, the most decisive member of this group. Her very versatile, well-rounded personality makes it very easy for almost everyone to like her.

Meanwhile, the Yellow in Han's image shows he has the sharp awareness needed to support superior piloting skills, and the Red shows he is amiable and willing to help. His pragmatism and emotion — represented by the Yellow and Red — are the opposite of Leia's idealism and logic — represented by the Blue and Green — fueling a strong attraction.

To learn more about a character's personality, click on their thumbnail to see a larger version, then click on the Show the Whole Story button to read the character's story.

image_list.title: Luke Skywalker
image_list.subtitle_html: Jedi Apprentice and Twin Brother of Leia Organa
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Luke's spiritual portrait shows he is idealistic and rational.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Luke's dominant personality trait, his openness to ideas and optimistic vision of the future.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Luke demonstrates this trait when he gets Yoda to train him in the ways of The Force so he can help fight for the ideal of freedom for everyone in the galaxy.
image_list.explain_aux: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Luke's auxiliary personality trait, his rationality, objectivity, and cool-headedness.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Luke demonstrates this trait when he remains calm, focused, and unemotional in crisis situations.  One such situation occurs when Jabba the Hutt tries to execute him, Han Solo, and Chewbacca to the sarlacc in the Great Pit of Carkoon on Tatooine.
image_list.story_intro_html:
When Luke Skywalker was a child growing up on the remote planet of Tatooine, he didn't realize he had a twin sister and the potential to become a Jedi Knight.

All this changes one day when he and his uncle purchase two droids, R2-D2 and C-3PO. R2-D2 is on a mission to deliver a message to Obi-Wan Kenobi, and the Galactic Empire is determined to stop the droid.

Had Enough of Tatooine

In the Empire's search for R2-D2, they kill Luke's adoptive parents, brutally burning their bodies to a crisp — probably while they were still alive. Luke is, however, able to help R2-D2 succeed in delivering the message to Obi-Wan.

The message is from Princess Leia, who is part of the Rebel Alliance. She is desperate for Obi-Wan's help in the fight for freedom against the Galactic Empire.

Obi-Wan asks Luke if he would be willing to help him help the Princess. Luke responds that he's had enough of Tatooine:

I want to come with you to Alderaan. There's nothing for me here now. I want to learn the ways of the Force and become a Jedi like my father.
 — Luke in A New Hope, 1977.

Luke has obviously felt stifled growing up on such a remote planet, and he was clearly horrified when he saw how the Empire murdered his adoptive parents in cold blood. When Obi-Wan tells him he'll have to sell his speeder, Luke responds somewhat bitterly, That's okay. I'm never coming back to this planet again.

Learning About the Force

Luke Skywalker's spiritual portrait, like those of his friend Obi-Wan Kenobi and his mentor Yoda, contains a lot of Blue. As with the other Jedi, the Blue represents his strong preference for ideas rather than facts, and the force is the single most important idea in the life of a Jedi.

Luke learns a few tidbits about the force from Obi-Wan, but his mentoring about the force doesn't start in earnest until he meets Yoda in Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back. After escaping from a monster's lair and struggling in a snowstorm, he has fallen down face-first in the snow. As he is lying there, the deceased Obi-Wan Kenobi appears to him, as if in a vision.

Obi-Wan Kenobi: Luke. Luke!
Luke Skywalker: Ben?
Obi-Wan: You will go to the Dagobah system.
Luke: Dagobah system.
Obi-Wan: There you will learn from Yoda, the Jedi Master who instructed me.
Luke: Ben! [Obi-Wan's image fades, replaced by the real live Han Solo.]
 — From The Empire Strikes Back, 1980.

On Dagobah, Yoda teaches him Jedi ideals and skills. ______,

Luke's training is cut a bit short when he senses his new friends, Leia and Han, are in trouble.

Luke: I saw a city in the clouds.
Yoda: Mmm. Friends you have there.
Luke: They were in pain.
Yoda: It is the future you see.
Luke: The future... Will they die?
Yoda: Difficult to say. Always in motion is the future.
 — From The Empire Strikes Back, 1980.

______.

Green: Logic

Luke Skywalker has a very weak preference for making logical rather than emotional decisions. When they first meet, Yoda picks up on Luke's prejudices and teases him a bit:

Yoda: Help you I can. Yes, mmm.
Luke: I don't think so. I'm looking for a great warrior.
Yoda: Oh! Great warrior. Wars not make one great.
 — From The Empire Strikes Back, 1980.

Luke: I don't want your help. I want my lamp back. I'm gonna need it to get out of this slimy mudhole.
Yoda: Mudhole? Slimy? My home this is!
 — From The Empire Strikes Back, 1980.

Later, over dinner, Yoda reveals his identity, and he and Luke build a strong mentoring relationship.

Luke lets his emotions — his love for his friends — get the better of him when he abandons his Jedi training before it's complete to go and rescue them.

Yoda: Only a fully trained Jedi knight, with the Force as his ally, will conquer Vader and his Emperor. If you end your training now, if you choose the quick and easy path, as Vader did, you will become an agent of evil.
Obi-Wan: Patience!
Luke: And sacrifice Han and Leia?
Yoda: If you honor what they fight for? Yes!
 — From The Empire Strikes Back, 1980.

Luke loses his fight with Vader, but fortunately Yoda's prediction does not come true.

Similar to Yoda and Obi-Wan

Maybe something here about ambiversion. Luke's score is very high, but in The Force Awakens he's turned into a total recluse. Hmm. See pp. 148-151 of Star Wars Psychology book.

About This Portrait

This spiritual portrait is based on the Star Wars original trilogy:

  • Episode IV: A New Hope, 1977
  • Episode V: The Empire Strikes Back, 1980
  • Episode VI: Return of the Jedi, 1983

The book Star Wars Psychology: The Dark Side of the Mind, by Travis Langley and with a forward by Carrie Goldman, was also helpful in creating these portraits. This excellent book is a collection of immensely entertaining and enlightening essays and if you are a fan of Star Wars, I recommend it highly!

image_list.title: Leia Organa
image_list.subtitle_html: Princess of Alderaan and Twin Sister of Luke Skywalker
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Leia's spiritual portrait shows she is a bit logical and idealistic, but very flexible and well-rounded.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in this spiritual portrait represents Leia's dominant personality trait, her very slight preference for logic over emotion.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Leia demonstrates her decisiveness in the way she asserts command after Obi-Wan, Luke, Han, and Chewbacca rescue her from Darth Vader in the original Star Wars, A New Hope.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in this spiritual portrait represents Leia's auxiliary personality trait, her very slight preference for ideas over facts.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Leia demonstrates her openness to ideas when she senses Luke is in trouble after his fight with Darth Vader at the end of The Empire Strikes Back, and insists they interrupt their escape to return to get him.

image_list.title: Han Solo
image_list.subtitle_html: Captain of the Millennium Falcon
image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Han Solo's spiritual portrait shows he is down to earth and amiable.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Yellow in this spiritual portrait represents Han's dominant personality trait, his realistic outlook and openness to new experiences.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  Han demonstrates this trait when he initially refuses to help Luke, Leia, and the Rebel Alliance in Star Wars IV, A New Hope, thinking that their fight against the Empire is not realistic, and that he has more important things to do than help his new friends in their mission.
image_list.explain_aux: The Red in this spiritual portrait represents Han's auxiliary personality trait, his amiability, warmth, and friendliness.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  Han demonstrates this trait when he has a change of heart and decides to return to help Luke, Leia, and the Rebel Alliance in their fight against the Empire, coming back to help destroy the Death Star near the ending in Star Wars IV, A New Hope.
